# Question 1


First, let's read in the data from the Excel file:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(readxl)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}
```
Warning: package 'readxl' was built under R version 4.1.3
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
library(tidyverse)
```

```{.r .cell-code}
library(dplyr)
df <- read_excel("_data/LungCapData.xls")
```
:::



## 1.a 

(The distribution of LungCap looks as follows:)

The histogram suggests that the distribution is close to a normal distribution. Most of the observations are close to the mean. Very few observations are close to the margins (0 and 15).


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
head(df)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 6 x 6
  LungCap   Age Height Smoke Gender Caesarean
    <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> <chr> <chr>  <chr>    
1    6.48     6   62.1 no    male   no       
2   10.1     18   74.7 yes   female no       
3    9.55    16   69.7 no    female yes      
4   11.1     14   71   no    male   no       
5    4.8      5   56.9 no    male   no       
6    6.22    11   58.7 no    female no       
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
hist(df$LungCap)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](HW1_EthanCampbell_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::




## 1.b 

(Comparing lung cap by gender)

Here we notice that males tend to have a higher lung cap compared to females. Females average tends to sit around 8 while males seems to sit closer to 9


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
boxplot(df$LungCap~df$Gender)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](HW1_EthanCampbell_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


## 1.c 

(smoker vs non-smoker lung cap)

Interestingly, none smokers tend to have a lower lung capacity however, I believe this might be due to age. No this does not make sense at first glance and does betray my expectation.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
df %>%
  group_by(Smoke) %>%
  summarize_at(vars(LungCap), list(mean = mean))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 2 x 2
  Smoke  mean
  <chr> <dbl>
1 no     7.77
2 yes    8.65
```
:::
:::


## 1.d 

(relation between smoking and lung cap at different age groups)

The lung cap starts off higher but takes and dip then rises as the age continues to grow. I believe the trend is the higher age grows the higher the lung cap until it reaches a certain point. 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# lung cap is 9.62
df %>%
  select(Age, LungCap) %>%
  filter(Age >= 13) %>%
  colMeans()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
      Age   LungCap 
15.609290  9.628757 
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# lung cap is 9.04
df %>%
  select(Age, LungCap) %>%
  filter(Age >= 14 & Age <= 15) %>%
  colMeans()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
      Age   LungCap 
14.533333  9.045417 
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# lung cap is 10.24
df %>%
  select(Age, LungCap) %>%
  filter(Age >= 16 & Age <= 17) %>%
  colMeans()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
     Age  LungCap 
16.44330 10.24588 
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# lung cap is 11.26
df %>%
  select(Age, LungCap) %>%
  filter(Age > 18) %>%
  colMeans()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
     Age  LungCap 
19.00000 11.26149 
```
:::
:::

## 1.e 

(lung cap for smokers and non smokers broken into age groups)

We notice a clear trend that smokers have a lower lung capacity compared to non-smokers


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
df %>%
  select(Age, LungCap, Smoke) %>%
  group_by(Smoke) %>%
  filter(Age >= 13) %>%
  summarize_at(vars(LungCap), list(mean = mean))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 2 x 2
  Smoke  mean
  <chr> <dbl>
1 no     9.71
2 yes    9.21
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
df %>%
  select(Age, LungCap, Smoke) %>%
  group_by(Smoke) %>%
  filter(Age >= 14 & Age <= 15) %>%
  summarize_at(vars(LungCap), list(mean = mean))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 2 x 2
  Smoke  mean
  <chr> <dbl>
1 no     9.14
2 yes    8.39
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
df %>%
  select(Age, LungCap, Smoke) %>%
  group_by(Smoke) %>%
  filter(Age >= 16 & Age <= 17) %>%
  summarize_at(vars(LungCap), list(mean = mean))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 2 x 2
  Smoke  mean
  <chr> <dbl>
1 no    10.5 
2 yes    9.38
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
df %>%
  select(Age, LungCap, Smoke) %>%
  group_by(Smoke) %>%
  filter(Age > 18) %>%
  summarize_at(vars(LungCap), list(mean = mean))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 2 x 2
  Smoke  mean
  <chr> <dbl>
1 no     11.3
2 yes    11.3
```
:::
:::

## 1.f 

(correlation and covariance between lung capacity and age)

correlation is at .819 meaning they have a positive correlation of about 82%. This means that there is a connection between the two and when one goes up so does the other. 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
cov(df$LungCap, df$Age)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 8.738289
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
cor(df$LungCap, df$Age)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 0.8196749
```
:::
:::

# Question 2


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# creating the Tibble
df <- tibble(X=c(0,1,2,3,4), Freq=c(128,434,160,64,26))

# Creating the probability of an event occurring
df1 <- df %>%
  select(X, Freq) %>%
  mutate(Probability = Freq/sum(Freq))
df1
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 5 x 3
      X  Freq Probability
  <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl>
1     0   128      0.158 
2     1   434      0.534 
3     2   160      0.197 
4     3    64      0.0788
5     4    26      0.0320
```
:::
:::


## 2.a

probability of exactly 2 convictions
probability = 19.7%


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
df1 %>%
  select(X, Freq, Probability) %>%
  filter(X == 2)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 1 x 3
      X  Freq Probability
  <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl>
1     2   160       0.197
```
:::
:::


## 2.b

probability of fewer than 2 convictions
probability = 69.2%


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
sum(df1$Probability[1:2])
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 0.6921182
```
:::
:::


## 2.c

Probability of having 2 or fewer convictions
probability = 88.9%


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
sum(df1$Probability[1:3])
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 0.8891626
```
:::
:::


## 2.d

probability of having more than 2 convictions
probability = 11.08%


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
sum(df1$Probability[4:5])
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 0.1108374
```
:::
:::


## 2.e

What is the expected value
expected value is 1.29 convictions 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
df1 %>%
  select(X, Freq, Probability) %>%
  mutate(expected_value = (0*0.15763547)+(1*0.53448276)+(2*0.19704433)+(3*0.07881773)+(4*0.03201970))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 5 x 4
      X  Freq Probability expected_value
  <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl>          <dbl>
1     0   128      0.158            1.29
2     1   434      0.534            1.29
3     2   160      0.197            1.29
4     3    64      0.0788           1.29
5     4    26      0.0320           1.29
```
:::
:::


## 2.f

What is the variance and standard deviation of the prior convictions
Variance = 25810.8
standard deviation = 160.6574

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
var(df$Freq)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 25810.8
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
sd(df$Freq)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 160.6574
```
:::
:::
